description: Professional sensory template for specialty-grade coffee evaluation with SCA-aligned methodology
expertNotes: Focus on origin characteristics, roast development, and brew method impact. Specialty coffee should score 80+ on SCA scale with distinct terroir expression.

appearance.prompt: Evaluate visual cues of coffee quality
appearance.expertTips: Light-to-medium roasts preserve origin character. Good crema (espresso) should be golden-brown with fine bubbles, not dark and coarse.

aroma.prompt: Assess aromatic complexity and intensity (dry grounds + brewed)
aroma.expertTips: Specialty coffee should show clear origin character. Ethiopian coffees often show floral/berry notes, while Latin American coffees lean toward chocolate/nuts.

frontMouth.prompt: Evaluate initial taste impact and acidity
keyAttributes: Acidity level and type (bright, citric, malic, soft)
frontMouth.expertTips: Acidity should be bright and pleasant, not sour or aggressive. Well-extracted coffee shows immediate complexity without harsh bitterness.

midRearMouth.prompt: Track flavor development and body perception
keyAttributes: Flavor notes emerging (fruit, chocolate, caramel, nuts)
midRearMouth.expertTips: This phase reveals coffee quality. Look for sweetness (natural sugars), complexity, and balance. Body should match origin expectations (e.g., Sumatra = full body).

aftertaste.prompt: Evaluate finish length, quality, and cleanliness
keyAttributes: Finish flavor character (sweet, fruity, cocoa, bitter)
aftertaste.expertTips: Specialty coffee should have a long, sweet, clean finish. Bitter or astringent aftertaste indicates over-extraction or poor quality. 20-30 second finish is typical of high-scoring coffee.

emotionalResponse.prompt: Capture the consumption experience and emotional connection
emotionalResponse.expertTips: Specialty coffee often becomes a daily ritual. Balance functional benefits (caffeine) with sensory pleasure for highest engagement.

benchmarkInsights: Specialty coffee (80+ SCA score) typically shows 8-9/10 repeat consumption. Balanced acidity (6-7/10) correlates with higher consumer acceptance than high acidity (8-9/10).
categoryTrends: Growing interest in light roasts, single-origin traceability, and natural/experimental processing. Consumer education on acidity vs. sourness is key.
